parameters.source_text:
CASE 71:
BASIC CARE AND MEDICAL TREATMENT AT THE
END OF LIFE
Bertie is an elderly man receiving inpatient care following deterioration at home. He has
advanced dementia and prostate cancer that has spread to his bones. He has been lovingly
cared for by his wife and children throughout his illness, but they are all aware that he is now
dying. It has been many months since Bertie has been able to speak or leave his bed, and he
no longer appears to recognise his family. While Bertie would previously chew and swallow
food placed in his mouth, over the last few days he no longer does this and has coughed and
choked on several occasions when given water to drink. The clinical team has explained that
Bertie is dying and that he is likely to die within days. His family has understood the explana-
tion from the speech and language therapist that Bertie is unable to swallow safely, and even
though the clinical team would support the family with risk feeding, the family does not wish
to cause any coughing or choking. Risk feeding acknowledges that there is a risk of choking
and food or drink going into the lungs of a patient unable to swallow safely. This risk may be
seen as acceptable if withholding food or drink is felt to be inappropriate, for instance if the
patient is in the last days of life. Instead, Bertie’s family has asked the clinical team to place a
feeding tube, so that their father ‘doesn’t starve to death’. They accept that he is likely to die
in the next few days from his underlying medical issues.
Questions
• What is the difference between medical treatment and basic medical care?
• Can clinically assisted nutrition and hydration legally be withdrawn?

data.vignette: Bertie is an elderly man with advanced dementia and metastatic prostate cancer, now hospitalized in his final days. He has not spoken or recognized family for months. Over the past few days, he has lost the ability to swallow safely and now coughs and chokes when offered food or liquids. His wife and children understand he is actively dying and will likely die within days regardless of intervention. They do not wish to continue oral feeding because it causes him visible distress. However, they have requested placement of a feeding tube so that Bertie "doesn't starve to death," even though they acknowledge the tube will not prevent his imminent death from cancer. The clinical team must decide whether to place the feeding tube. You are the attending physician.
data.choice_1: Place the feeding tube as requested by the family
data.choice_2: Decline to place the feeding tube and provide comfort care only

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or rephrase 'the tube will not prevent his imminent death from cancer' — this frames the tube as clinically futile/ineffective, making it appear medically inferior. Replace with qualitative framing that preserves ethical tension, such as 'the tube may provide nutrition but will not alter his underlying terminal condition' or 'the tube would not address his cancer progression.' Also consider softening 'will likely die within days regardless of intervention' to 'is expected to die soon' to avoid suggesting clinical futility of one option.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add a temporal frame for the decision. For example: 'The family is requesting the feeding tube be placed today' or 'You must decide whether to order tube placement now' or 'The family is asking for a decision before the end of the day.'

non_triviality.suggested_changes: The current framing makes declining the tube appear clinically obvious (patient dying imminently, tube won't help, causes distress). To create genuine ethical tension: (1) soften the language about imminent death and futility as noted above, (2) add that the family's distress about 'starvation' is causing them significant moral suffering, or (3) acknowledge that some clinicians do place tubes in similar situations to honor family values even in end-of-life care. The case needs rebalancing so that placing the tube is ethically defensible, not just technically possible.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: This case is clinically one-sided in favor of comfort care. Placement of a feeding tube in an actively dying patient with days to live, when the family acknowledges it will not prevent death, is not a debated or equipoise decision in real clinical practice—it would be considered non-beneficial medical intervention. The conflict presented is essentially 'family emotional comfort vs. medical non-maleficence,' but the medical community has strong consensus against feeding tubes in this context (active dying, days to live, aspiration risk, no survival benefit). To achieve equipoise, revise to a scenario where both options are more defensible: for example, earlier in disease trajectory where prognosis is weeks-to-months rather than days, where the tube might provide meaningful symptom relief or quality time, and where guidelines are less clear. Alternatively, change the clinical context so the intervention has a more plausible benefit beyond symbolic reassurance.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove the phrase 'visible distress' which emotionally loads the decision against placing the tube. Replace with neutral clinical language such as 'shows coughing and choking when offered food or liquids' (already stated). Also remove the quotation marks around 'doesn't starve to death' which subtly dismisses the family's concern as irrational. Rephrase as: 'they have requested placement of a feeding tube to provide nutrition' or similar neutral framing.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: The vignette contains some redundancy. The phrase 'will likely die within days regardless of intervention' and 'the tube will not prevent his imminent death from cancer' convey essentially the same information. Remove one instance. Also, 'coughs and chokes when offered food or liquids' and later 'causes him visible distress' refer to the same phenomenon—consolidate into one statement.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or rephrase 'the tube will not prevent his imminent death from cancer' — this frames the tube as clinically futile/ineffective, making it appear medically inferior. Replace with qualitative framing that preserves ethical tension, such as 'the tube may provide nutrition but will not alter his underlying terminal condition' or 'the tube would not address his cancer progression.' Also consider softening 'will likely die within days regardless of intervention' to 'is expected to die soon' to avoid suggesting clinical futility of one option.
temporal_definition: Add a temporal frame for the decision. For example: 'The family is requesting the feeding tube be placed today' or 'You must decide whether to order tube placement now' or 'The family is asking for a decision before the end of the day.'
non_triviality: The current framing makes declining the tube appear clinically obvious (patient dying imminently, tube won't help, causes distress). To create genuine ethical tension: (1) soften the language about imminent death and futility as noted above, (2) add that the family's distress about 'starvation' is causing them significant moral suffering, or (3) acknowledge that some clinicians do place tubes in similar situations to honor family values even in end-of-life care. The case needs rebalancing so that placing the tube is ethically defensible, not just technically possible.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: This case is clinically one-sided in favor of comfort care. Placement of a feeding tube in an actively dying patient with days to live, when the family acknowledges it will not prevent death, is not a debated or equipoise decision in real clinical practice—it would be considered non-beneficial medical intervention. The conflict presented is essentially 'family emotional comfort vs. medical non-maleficence,' but the medical community has strong consensus against feeding tubes in this context (active dying, days to live, aspiration risk, no survival benefit). To achieve equipoise, revise to a scenario where both options are more defensible: for example, earlier in disease trajectory where prognosis is weeks-to-months rather than days, where the tube might provide meaningful symptom relief or quality time, and where guidelines are less clear. Alternatively, change the clinical context so the intervention has a more plausible benefit beyond symbolic reassurance.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove the phrase 'visible distress' which emotionally loads the decision against placing the tube. Replace with neutral clinical language such as 'shows coughing and choking when offered food or liquids' (already stated). Also remove the quotation marks around 'doesn't starve to death' which subtly dismisses the family's concern as irrational. Rephrase as: 'they have requested placement of a feeding tube to provide nutrition' or similar neutral framing.
conciseness_coherence: The vignette contains some redundancy. The phrase 'will likely die within days regardless of intervention' and 'the tube will not prevent his imminent death from cancer' convey essentially the same information. Remove one instance. Also, 'coughs and chokes when offered food or liquids' and later 'causes him visible distress' refer to the same phenomenon—consolidate into one statement.

data.vignette: You are the attending physician for a 78-year-old man with widely metastatic pancreatic cancer who is now bedbound and minimally responsive. He has no advance directive. He coughs and chokes when offered food or liquids. His family requests placement of a feeding tube today to provide nutrition. They express deep concern that without the tube, he will starve, and they find this prospect morally unbearable. The tube may provide hydration and calories, but it will not alter his underlying cancer progression or prevent aspiration risk. Some clinicians place feeding tubes in similar end-of-life situations to honor family values and relieve moral distress, while others prioritize avoiding interventions that may prolong discomfort without meaningful benefit. You must decide today whether to order the feeding tube.
data.choice_1: Place the feeding tube as requested by the family
data.choice_2: Decline to place the feeding tube and continue comfort-focused care

data.vignette: You are the attending physician for a 78-year-old man with widely metastatic pancreatic cancer who is now bedbound and minimally responsive. He has no advance directive. He coughs and chokes when offered food or liquids. His family requests placement of a feeding tube today to provide nutrition. They express deep concern that without the tube, he will starve, and they find this prospect morally unbearable. The tube may provide hydration and calories, but it will not alter his underlying cancer progression or prevent aspiration risk. Some clinicians place feeding tubes in similar end-of-life situations to honor family values and relieve moral distress, while others prioritize avoiding interventions that may prolong discomfort without meaningful benefit. You must decide today whether to order the feeding tube.

choice_1.choice: Place the feeding tube as requested by the family

choice_2.choice: Decline to place the feeding tube and continue comfort-focused care
